video.title: Python Microservices Web App (with React, Django, Flask) - Full Course
video.description:
Using Python microservices allows you to break up your apps into smaller parts that communicate with each other. This can make it simpler to scale the application based on the traffic. Also, the separation of concerns makes it easier to work on just one part of the app at a time.

💻 Code - Python Microservices: https://github.com/scalablescripts/python-microservices
💻 Code - React: https://github.com/scalablescripts/react-crud

✏️ Course developed by Scalable Scripts. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SzsPe_QX__c

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) What are Microservices?
⌨️ (0:02:29) Project Introduction
⌨️ (0:05:29) Django Setup
⌨️ (0:06:31) Adding Docker Files
⌨️ (0:12:32) Connect Django with MySQL with Docker
⌨️ (0:19:12) Models & Serializers
⌨️ (0:23:11) Rest APIs with ViewSets
⌨️ (0:35:07) User Endpoint with APIView
⌨️ (0:37:53) Flask Setup with Docker
⌨️ (0:42:13) Connect Flask with Mysql
⌨️ (0:44:00) Models
⌨️ (0:47:41) Flask Migrations
⌨️ (0:51:44) RabbitMQ
⌨️ (0:52:15) Django Producer and Consumer
⌨️ (0:57:54) Flask Producer and Consumer
⌨️ (0:59:25) Queue Service
⌨️ (1:04:18) Data Consistency
⌨️ (1:14:36) Internal Http Requests
⌨️ (1:18:06) Finishing the python apps
⌨️ (1:25:51) React Setup
⌨️ (1:42:04) Products CRUD
⌨️ (2:08:44) Completing the Main App

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Harlin Seritt
topLevelComment.text: So far, a fantastic tutorial. I got stuck for a moment on the MySQL client (error: ssl_choose_client_version:unsupported protocol) ... was able to just turn off the use SSL option on the SSL tab of the connection. I will come back with more info as I go through it today. Thanks much for putting this out there!

replies.author: Saikat Roy
replies.text:
Put this 3 on your requirements.txt file of main app and you are good to go.
jinja2<3.1.0
itsdangerous==2.0.1
Werkzeug==2.0.0
since it's using old version this files are needed. Updated versions doesn't use it anymore. That's what causing the problems.

topLevelComment.author: krazymusicguy
topLevelComment.text: This is too much for a YouTube comment, but http requests shouldn't be made between microservices. You're increasing failure modes and latency; nothing is being uncoupled here and you'd be better off with shared libraries and shared access. Message driven services, which is where this started is the medium to do this effectively.

topLevelComment.author: Gokul Kurup
topLevelComment.text:
Great tutorial, but around 1:02 when you run the container its very important to run python -u consumer.py and not python consumer.py
This disables buffering in the output. what that means is instead of waiting for a finished output, it asynchronously outputs values

Those running on linux use
 req = requests.get('http://172.17.0.1:8000/api/user')

and add 172.17.0.1 to django's ALLOWED_HOSTS

im assuming that your mysql is added into PATH

topLevelComment.author: FLAKEYNAVI
topLevelComment.text:
If you are using a newer version of docker:  docker.for.mac.localhost wont work. You have to change it to:
 host.docker.internal
And If you are using Linux you have to use the docker IP, which is 
172.17.0.1
But you have to add this URL in your Django setting.py, like this:
ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['172.17.0.1']

topLevelComment.author: Yusuf Aydın
topLevelComment.text:
Docker version error for Fields:

Step 1:
sudo curl -L "https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.28.2/docker-compose-$(uname -s)-$(uname -m)" -o /usr/local/bin/docker-compose
Step 2:
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-compose

Note: Remove the first installed docker version and solution for Linux

replies.author: FLAKEYNAVI
replies.text: In docker 20.10 is now  'host.docker.internal' , and doen not work in linux. In linux use the docker ip: 172.17.0.1 and add that IP to your allowed host on Django settings.pt, like this: ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['172.17.0.1']

topLevelComment.author: Max Spekle
topLevelComment.text:
Great video! Learnt a ton out of it! Thanks! 

One comment for my understanding though...

Maybe I've missed something but at 2:09:56, the fetch() call in useEffect() of Main.tsx is sent to the Main/Flask App: 'localhost:8001/api/products'. However, the flask app does not keep likes in its db, so the number of likes is not received back and is not reflected on the 'localhost:3000' page; and on hitting the Like button, 'NoN' is shown instead of a number.

After changing the port in that fetch() to '8000', which makes the GET sent to Admin/Django instead, the likes on localhost:3000 work ok. 

Also, the number of likes in the Admin/Django db may mismatch such number on the localhost:3000 on hitting the Like button many times, because the Django app will not increment it for a repeated  user id - product id pair while the number of likes on  the page is incremented irrespectively. This can easily be tweaked, I think.

replies.author: Zbigniew Stankowicz
replies.text: on Linux - instead of host.docker.internal just use the IP of the respective docker container (command 'ip a' will list all) . Make sure that you add those IPs in the tutorial project (django) in admin/admin/settings.py file. Or for the sake of simplicity use ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['*'] there (don't use on production) instead of listing the IPs.

topLevelComment.author: Dev Internals
topLevelComment.text:
At 1:14:36 where the author started to make internal requests, the docker.for.mac.localhost was only for Mac users. In linux I have fixed the issue with following steps:
1. Get the IP address of your docker host machine:
`ip addr show enx000ec78ee217 ` -> for me it is 192.168.5.122
2. Check the route if the docker can access to this default network:
route
Kernel IP routing table
Destination     Gateway         Genmask         Flags Metric Ref    Use Iface
default         _gateway        0.0.0.0         UG    100    0        0 enx000ec78ee217
default         _gateway        0.0.0.0         UG    600    0        0 wlp3s0
link-local      0.0.0.0         255.255.0.0     U     1000   0        0 wlp3s0
172.17.0.0      0.0.0.0         255.255.0.0     U     0      0        0 docker0
So yes.
3. requests.get('http://192.168.5.122:8000/api/user') -> type IP address.
4. Add this address inside settings.py ->  ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['192.168.5.122']
5. Curl to like:
curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8001/api/products/5/like
{
  "id": 2
}

replies.author: Northern
replies.text: Also as a note, If you're following along and running this via docker for windows, you use docker.for.win.localhost in place. Took me a minute to figure out it wanted the shortened version. Happy coding.

replies.author: Deep
replies.text:
However, for Linux users, here is a simpler solution

-- If you're running with --net=host, localhost should work fine. If you're using default networking, use the static IP 172.17.0.1

-- The static IP can be got using the following command:

`$(ip addr show | grep "\binet\b.*\bdocker0\b" | awk '{print $2}' | cut -d '/' -f 1)`
OUTPUT: 172.17.0.1

-- Add the new IP to allowed hosts in django app's, settings.py

`ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['172.17.0.1', 'localhost']`

-- Now change the request URL to this

req = requests.get('http://172.17.0.1:8000/api/user')

topLevelComment.author: vinny142
topLevelComment.text:
Microservices can solve a problem, but beware that you create a *lot* of new problems that are much harder to solve than the "problem" of scaling a monolith.

For example: at the start of the video the example shows that every microservice has it's own database, but the productlist, the search and the product recommnedations *MUST* have the exact same list of products to work with so  all three datbases must contain the same data and so you end up storing all productdata three times. More problematically, you have to keep the data synchronized through the eventbus. That is a very very *VERY* bad idea. Databases like postgreSQL can replicate simple tables but again that is usually a bad design.


Think VERY hard about wether you want a microservice setup and WHY you need it. Don't follow a hype here, KNOW what you are getting into before you commit because you can dig a very deep hole for yourself very quickly.

replies.author: fabian sarmiento
replies.text: Hype? microservices architecture has been with us for YEARS and is quite proven in the practice and theory that there is plenty of use cases where is valid and also necessary.
